results.title: Music of the spheres
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Dick Gilling, Time-Life Films and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Jacob Bronowski discusses the influence of mathematics and numbers on culture throughout the ages. Going back to the time of Pythagorus, he demonstrates how his mathematical formula influenced Greek music and thought; how it was adapted in Alexandria by people such as Ptolemy; the development of symmetry art and culture; to the translation of numerical thought into Latin and its effect on perspective, depth and dimension in art. Throughout, it is stressed by Bronowski how the inner eye of the painter and the logic of the mathematician have combined in the development of art and culture. Written and narrated by Jacob Bronowski. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrian Malone, Dick Gilling, Time-Life Films and BBC-TV

results.title: Music of the masters: 'Jesu, joy of man's desiring' Bach
results.brief_description: Prayerful lyricism of this Bach piece celebrated in H. Dexter’s sensitive arrangement for chamber trio (David Martin - violin; Barnard Richards - cello; Marie Goosens - harp). Delicate graceful gestures of the players are an apt counterpoint to the beauty of the music.

results.title: Music of India: instrumental
results.creator_credit: A. Bhaskar Rao, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: A number of musical instruments are shown. Saraswati veena is a favourite stringed instrument of Southern India. Denai is a reed instrument, usually played in company with several other instruments. Sursazar is a complicated string instrument; the strings are plucked with the left hand and bowed with the right, at the same time. Sitar is a plucked string instrument, and one of the best known of Indian instruments. Tabla and baya are drums, played together, one with each hand; they are mostly used for accompaniment, but sometimes are played alone.
results.creator_credit_for_label: A. Bhaskar Rao, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India

results.title: Music lessons (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Describes how the Kodaly method of music instruction is being applied in American schools. The progression of learning; the training required to teach the method; the preparation for each lesson, and the commitment schools must make if they choose to adopt this method.

results.title: Music killers
results.brief_description:
A look at how to “kill” music, now and 300 years later. This offbeat music piece uses a combination of live action and animation.
Graduate work from RMIT media arts (BA Arts)

results.title: Music is Sweet
results.brief_description: Share the joy of music with these amazing young voices from Poowong Consolidated School. Meet the kids and teachers of this inspirational primary school where writing, recording and performing songs is taught hand-in-hand with all the other standard subjects. Students of all grades are given the opportunity to express themselves through music and to perform their songs infront of their peers and the community.

results.title: Music in the woods: plus four other stories
results.creator_credit: Ellen Meske, Jackie Cockle and Cosgrove Hall Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Animal shelf”.
Five stories are contained on this tape comprising MUSIC IN THE WOODS, THE ANIMAL GARDEN, WOEFUL AND THE WASPBERRIES, TIDYING TIMOTHY’S BEDROOM and GUMPA SOLVES A JIGSAW PUZZLE. MUSIC IN THE WOODS: Timothy and the special animals spend a day in the woods collecting feathers. As a precaution against any animals getting lost, they take their musical instruments to play if they get lost in the woods. In the woods they meet a new friend, the Parrot, but they soon realise that Little Mut is missing. THE ANIMAL GARDEN: The animals are given their own garden to look after by Timothy. Nothing seems to be growing, until Woeful and Gumpa decide to help things along. WOEFUL AND THE WASPBERRIES: The animals decide to organise a surprise birthday picnic for Timothy and they are all caught up in the preparations, except for Woeful who has forgotten all about Timothy’s birthday. Luckily he has an idea for a present, but it’s an idea that will lead him into all sorts of trouble. TIDYING TIMOTHY’S BEDROOM: When Timothy gets into trouble for having a messy bedroom, the animals decide to surprise him by tidying it themselves. There’s a prize for the first one to finish up, but there are even more surprises in store, especially for Timothy. GUMPA SOLVES A JIGSAW PUZZLE: Timothy and the animals are working on a jigsaw when Timothy is called in for tea. When they resume the puzzle after dinner, they discover a piece missing and the animals must perform a bit of detective work to find the missing piece.
